title: Full Stack App Build | Travel Log w/ Nuxt, Vue, Better Auth, Drizzle, Tailwind, DaisyUI, MapLibre

rawLines.text: Welcome to this build series where we'll
be building an application that allows
users to keep track of all the places
that they've visited. Now, in this
video, we're going to be building it
with Nux. But if you somehow clicked on
this video and you're not interested in
Nux, please leave a comment down below
because I will be building this app with
other meta frameworks like Tanstack
Start or Nex.js or Solid or SpeltKit.
So, if you're interested in seeing this
app built in any of those other
frameworks, let me know down in the
comments. But this video is all about
Next. Now, like I said, the app that
we're building allows users to keep
track of all the locations that they've
visited. So, you can see here on the
map, we have all these top level
locations. And then for any location, we
can dial in to a nested route. And these
are all the specific times that I
visited that location. In this example,
I'm just keeping track of all the live
shows that I went to in Denver last
year. But you can see now that I've
dialed in, we have these shows. They're
on the map. I can then dial in further
and we can view all the images that I
uploaded for this specific location log.
Everything you see in the app is
credible or create, read, update,
deletable. So for any given location, I
can update its details. For any specific
log, I can update its details. Every
single form in the app has client side
validation as well as server side
validation. And we pay attention to the
little things. So if a user starts
changing the data for a form and they
try to go back, we let them know, hey,
you might lose your progress. Now,
there's lots of other bits of nice user
experience things that we have in here.
So for instance, if I want to add
another location to the map, let's say
we add Washington DC. Whenever we
search, we show that loading spinner. We
let the user know that something's
happening. And there's lots of nice map
interactions here. So if I choose a
location, it'll pan over and zoom to
that location. Because we're using Nux,
when we're using this app, we kind of
have a hybrid approach. So the initial
page load when you visit the website is
serverside rendered but then as you
start to navigate around this actually
uses client side rendering and behaves
more as a single page application. So I
highly recommend go try the app out. If
you visit
nux-travel-log.verell.app you can click
around you can sign up. You can try
adding things and you'll notice things
are fairly zippy. Of course we do have
loading spinners because we're talking
to a database. is like network latency,

there's a lot of shared data in this
application as well, right? When we're
on the main dashboard here, we have all

highlighted on the map. We also have
these items in the sidebar. And when I
hover over on the map, they highlight in

using global shared state throughout our
application that allows all of these

locations/lug. If we dive into a

Of course, we're using Nux.js, which is

we're using several external libraries.
For the front end, we'll be using

UI component library built on top of

So all of our buttons will have nice
icons to indicate to the user what they
actually do. And throughout the app,
because we have multiple levels of
routing and lots of pages, we will be
using PIA, which is the global state
management solution in the Vue.js
ecosystem. So we'll have several PIA
stores that allow us to share data
throughout our application. For the map
portion of the application, we're going
to be using an open source library
called map libre. It's completely free
to use, no usage tokens or anything like
that. And for our tile server, we'll
also be using a completely free tile
server called open free map. Our app is
also going to allow users to search for
points of interest on the map. And for
that, we're going to be using the nomen
atm search API which comes from open
street map. And all of the search
results we get back there will be
caching using unsto. For form
validation, we'll be using a library
called validate and we'll pair that with
zod. So we'll have ZOD schemas for every
single thing that we'll be sending to
our API and that will also be validated
on the front end before it even makes it
to the back end using Validate and Zod.
For our database and OM we'll be using
Drizzle OM which is the best TypeScript
OM and we'll be talking to a lib SQL
database which is SQLite. Now we'll pair
that with Drizzle Zod which gives us Zod
schemas for all of the tables that we
defined where the single source of truth
is that TypeScript definition for our
table and then those Zod schemas can be
shared and used by all of our forms for
validation. So we have full type safety
here with a single source of truth. So
all of our validations on the front end
are the exact same validations that are
happening on the back end as well. Now
next is built on top of a framework
called Nitro which in turn is built on
top of a runtime agnostic API framework
called H3. So the file-based routing
throughout the application and also all
of our API routes are going to be
defined using Nitro and H3 functions.
For authentication we're going to be
using better off with GitHub. Better
comes with a Nux integration that works
well. They provide a client side and a
serverside library. And all of the
routes throughout our application are
going to be locked down so that only
logged in users can perform actions. And
when a user is retrieving data, they
only can retrieve data that they
specifically have access to. Users will
be able to upload images inside of our
app. And for that, we're going to be
using S3 compatible storage. And then
lastly, to make sure that we have a
really nice clean codebase, we're going
to be using ESLint combined with Husky
pre-commit hooks and also lint staged.
And every PR we make to our git repo is
going to run through a GitHub action to
run all of our lint tasks to make sure
our code is in a good state before it
gets merged in. And from there, any
merged code automatically will be
deployed using Verscell. Now, one of the
aspects of this architecture and how
we're going to be deploying and working
locally is that we're not locked in to
any service or thirdparty provider. You
might have seen a lot of tutorials out
there that are using hosted O services
or specific kinds of like hosted
databases. Our app can run entirely
locally on our machine and we can
actually change where our database is
hosted, where our images are hosted,
where we're deploying to. We're using
Verscell like I said, but Nux actually
supports lots of different deployment
providers. So, we could change all of
that as well. So, this is one thing that
I really harp on when we're building
this application is too much dependency
on thirdparty services can make it
really hard to work on a larger team to
be able to share those resources. So,
being able to have everything run
locally and every developer on your team
being able to run that stack locally is
a huge win. So specifically for our
SQLite database, when we're running
locally, we'll be using Terso dev. This
just spins up a local Terso server. So I
can talk to a local SQLite database. And
then when we're running in production,
we'll be using Terso cloud. For the app
itself, when we're running locally,
we're using the V dev server. And then
when we deploy, it'll be running on
Verso. Like I said, NX supports a lot of
different hosting providers. So we could
swap that out if we wanted to. For S3
compatible storage, we're going to be
using an open source project called
Min.io when we're running locally. So
this just runs inside of a Docker
container. It has an S3 compatible API.
So our app actually uses the AWS S3 SDK,
but we just point it to Min.io when
we're running locally. And then whenever
we deploy, we actually point to an AWS
S3 bucket in the cloud. And then for our
UNS storage caching, this is just using
the local file system module, but unsto
also supports a lot of different key
value storage providers like Reddus or
Upstash. So we don't actually set that
up in this tutorial, but because Nux is
using Nitro, which is using Unsto, you
actually can swap this out for any key
value provider. So this is our
architecture. This is what we're going
to be using. But throughout this
tutorial, anytime I'm choosing one of

uploading an image to an S3 bucket,
there's two ways to go about it. One way
is for our client to upload the image
directly to our server. So in Nux,
they're in the same app, but this is
essentially the client making an API
request and sending that image directly
to the server. then this server could
resize the image or validate the image,
do some various things and then upload
the image via the S3 API to that S3
bucket. Now, this is definitely the way
to go if you want to do your image
resizing on the server. But the one
issue with this is your server is going
to incur bandwidth for this because
every image that gets uploaded that is
data that's traveling to your server and
then that server has to upload that data
to your S3 API. So right now we're
deployed to Verscell and that means that
we're going to have some usage costs for
every single image that gets uploaded to
our server that's running on an edge
function. The other thing about this is
because this is an edge function, you
could run into time constraints if it
needs to do the processing on the server
because that edge function could time
out. So the way we'll handle this
instead is with pre-signed URLs. And the
way this will work is our client will
first make a request to our server and
ask for a pre-signed URL. And in order
to create that pre-signed URL, we need
the AWS secret and the AWS key. So the
server uses the secret in the key to get
a signed URL from the S3 API and then
returns that back to the client. Now
with that signed URL, the client can
upload directly to the S3 API without
needing to know our AWS secret. So this
is a short-lived URL. You can set an
expiration on it. And essentially this
URL is a special URL for uploading that
one image and then the client can upload
that image directly to the S3 API which
then puts it into the S3 bucket. And
this is the way to go especially if you
don't want to have all of that bandwidth
of those images being uploaded to your
server. Now because we're doing this
flow, if we want to resize the image or
change the quality in any way, we're
going to have to do it on the client
side. So that's what we'll do. But
whenever you generate this signed URL,
you can add several constraints inside
of it. So, we're going to assign
constraints that say it must be of a
specific file type. It must be under a
specific size, and then that's what the
client will use to upload the image. So,
even though we're doing this image
transformation on the client, we're
still at least restricting the size and
the type. A bad actor technically could
generate this URL and just upload junk
data, but by limiting the size, we're
we're limiting like incurring like any
really big S3 bill. And one final piece
to this flow after the client has
uploaded that image to the S3 bucket via
that signed URL is to then make a
request to the API with the key to that
uploaded image. And so that's step four
